author: By Parul Sehgal
title: ‘100 Boyfriends’ Tells Lewd and Lonely Stories of Desire and Heartbreak
description: In Brontez Purnell’s new book, a rotating cast of narrators share their experiences of erotic adventure and emotional need.
content: For all the chaos of which he seems singularly capable, the ex-boyfriend remains a strangely underrepresented character in literature. We might have Gatsby, Baldwin’s Giovanni, any number of Emma Bovary’s paramours (if they qualify), but I can rattle off twice as many charismatic fictional cats, and almost as many pigs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Europe’s Vaccine Mess
description: New coronavirus cases are declining in countries with high vaccination rates. Then there is Europe.
content: It is the latest sign of the power of the Covid-19 vaccines: The number of new cases is declining, often sharply, in countries that have vaccinated a large share of residents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Hess
title: This Is Your Brain on Peloton
description: The exercise bike company’s virtual classes represent an intense new genre of content: a total curation of the mind.
content: I think I’ve discovered the key to an active lifestyle. His name is Cody Rigsby, and he looks like a piece of Disney fan art — the kind where cartoon princes are rendered as photo-realistic living boys.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joanne Kaufman
title: The ‘Sentimental Excess’ of Sarah Stiles
description: The actor, who stars in the Netflix series ‘The Crew’ and is a regular on ‘Billions,’ is like a slightly goofy sitcom neighbor with an otherworldly home.
content: Sarah Stiles’s first address in New York was the Stratford Arms, an Upper West Side building that serves as campus housing for students at the American Musical and Dramatic Academy. Fittingly, the experience had its share of theatrics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos and Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: House Tackles Biden’s Immigration Plans Amid Migrant Influx
description: Democrats are preparing to push the first pieces of President Biden’s immigration plan through the House this week as a migrant surge threatens to unravel an already delicate coalition.
content: Democrats are preparing to push legislation through the House this week that would create a path to citizenship for millions of undocumented immigrants, posing the first tests to President Biden’s immigration agenda just as an influx of migrants is creating a new challenge at the border.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Cadaver Dogs Search Property Linked to ‘Prime Suspect’ in Kristin Smart Case
description: Paul Flores, the last person to see Ms. Smart before her disappearance in May 1996, continues to be the focus of investigators, the authorities said.
content: Nearly 25 years after the disappearance of the college student Kristin Smart in California, the search for clues in her death has intensified, with investigators using cadaver dogs and ground-penetrating radar on Monday to canvass a property connected to a “prime suspect,” the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kwame Anthony Appiah
title: I’m Not Eligible for the Vaccine Yet. Can I Hunt for a Surplus Dose?
description: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on whether securing a dose for yourself means taking someone else’s spot in line — and more.
content: I’m a college student, and I recently learned that my city is going to be opening up spots on the Health Department website for anyone to be vaccinated if there is a surplus of vaccines. We’re still in the first phase of vaccination, but if I were to look frequently at the vaccination website, I could in theory get an appointment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora
title: Regulator Vouches for AstraZeneca, Despite Suspension by European Countries
description: The suspension impedes Europe’s already troubled vaccination campaign amid a third coronavirus wave. Europe’s top drug regulator said there was no sign that the shot had caused dangerous side effects.
content: LONDON — After the European Union’s biggest countries suspended the use of AstraZeneca’s vaccine, the continent’s top drug regulator pushed back hard on Tuesday against fears about the shot, saying there was no sign of its causing rare but dangerous problems, and strong evidence that its lifesaving benefits “outweigh the risk of the side effects.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Tiny Love Stories: ‘Mami Sent Me to Check You Out’
description: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
content: As a dutiful girlfriend, I accompanied Arturo to JFK airport to pick up his sister, who was arriving from Buenos Aires. Greeting her, I casually asked what brought her to New York. “Mami sent me to check you out,” she said. Years later, Mami was visiting us. She offered to buy me a replacement diamond for the one that fell out of my engagement ring. “Oh, I can’t allow you to buy me something so expensive,” I said. Her reply? “Please do, because you are everything I hoped for in a wife for my son.” How could I refuse? — Phyllis Meyers
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Collins-Hughes
title: Instant Artifacts of a Disconnected Time (and Lots of Hugh Dancy)
description: During the pandemic, writers and actors have taken on an “adrenalizing” challenge: creating video monologues, more than 400 so far, in 24 hours.
content: The 24 Hour Plays move fast. That’s been their nature since their first production in 1995: short plays written, rehearsed and performed onstage in a scant 24-hour span. And when the pandemic shuttered theaters, the 24 Hour Plays responded with astonishing alacrity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Denise Grady
title: Moderna begins testing its vaccine in babies and young children.
description: The company plans to study healthy children ages six months through 11 years old in the U.S. and Canada.
content: The drug company Moderna has begun a study that will test its Covid vaccine in children under 12, including babies as young as six months, the company said on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chloe Benjamin
title: The Show Is About to Begin, Onstage and in the Audience’s Minds
description: In “The Performance,” Claire Thomas raises the curtain on the lives of three women who attend the same play on a hot summer night.
content: THE PERFORMANCEBy Claire Thomas
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jan Hoffman and Mary Williams Walsh
title: Purdue Pharma Offers Plan to End Sackler Control and Mounting Lawsuits
description: The OxyContin maker filed its long-awaited restructuring plan in bankruptcy court. Revenue from the new company would go exclusively to abating the opioid crisis.
content: In a filing that signifies the beginning of the end of the country’s most notorious manufacturer of prescription opioids, Purdue Pharma submitted its bankruptcy restructuring plan just before midnight on Monday. The blueprint requires members of the billionaire Sackler family to relinquish control of the company and transforms it into a new corporation with revenue directed exclusively toward abating the addiction epidemic that its signature painkiller, OxyContin, helped create.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes
title: Russian Interference in 2020 Included Influencing Trump Associates, Report Says
description: The assessment was the intelligence community’s most comprehensive look at foreign efforts to interfere in the election.
content: WASHINGTON — President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia authorized extensive efforts to hurt the candidacy of Joseph R. Biden Jr. during the election last year, including by mounting covert operations to influence people close to President Donald J. Trump, according to a declassified intelligence report released on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alida Becker
title: Three Historical Novels Explore the Strength of Human Connection
description: From a Nevada “divorce ranch” to literary Dublin to 19th-century Sweden, these characters put relationships to the test.
content: It’s easy to see why Julia Claiborne Johnson filled BETTER LUCK NEXT TIME (Custom House, 288 pp., $28.99) with movie-star look-alikes. Doesn’t a romantic comedy set on a 1930s Nevada dude ranch teeming with about-to-be-divorced women owe a certain debt to the era’s big-screen classics? Then again, it’s hard to believe a cinematic version could be any more fun than the small-page antics of the aptly named Flying Leap’s two hired hands and the pair of wealthy “guests” who seem determined to make their required stint as legal state residents as memorable as possible.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: Can Anything End the Voting Wars?
description: As battles over voting rules burn hotter, the stakes are still lower than both sides seem to think.
content: About two years ago I did something foolish: I wrote an optimistic column arguing that a polarizing issue was ripe for de-escalation and compromise.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elian Peltier
title: Prince Philip Leaves London Hospital
description: The 99-year-old husband of Queen Elizabeth was admitted after feeling ill and was hospitalized for 28 days, during which he had surgery for a pre-existing heart condition.
content: LONDON — Prince Philip, the 99-year-old husband of Queen Elizabeth, left a London hospital on Tuesday, according to Buckingham Palace, a month after he was initially hospitalized and later treated for a heart problem.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruchika Tulshyan
title: Why Is It So Hard to Speak Up at Work?
description: Psychological safety is the belief that you can take risks and put forward ideas without facing ridicule or retaliation. More often than not, it’s women — especially women of color — who don’t feel comfortable doing so.
content: — Sacha Thompson, who advises clients on diversity and inclusion in the workplace.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Buckley
title: The Rock Standing in the Way of China’s Climate Ambitions: Coal
description: Beijing’s new development blueprint is meant to steer the country to carbon neutrality before 2060, but companies and regions dependent on the fossil fuel aren’t making it easy.
content: Xi Jinping, China’s top leader, has promoted an uplifting vision for growth increasingly freed from greenhouse gas pollution, but turning that plan into action is already proving contentious.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kermit Pattison
title: When the Aliens Arrive, What Will They Look Like? A Zoologist Has Answers
description: In “A Zoologist’s Guide to the Galaxy,” Arik Kershenbaum uses his knowledge of the various species here on Earth to speculate about what might exist out there.
content: THE ZOOLOGIST’S GUIDE TO THE GALAXYWhat Animals on Earth Reveal About Aliens — and OurselvesBy Arik Kershenbaum
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeff Asher
title: Murder Rate Remains Elevated as New Crime Reporting System Begins
description: The switch in data collection will be a “leap forward,” but in the short term it may hurt the public’s ability to evaluate key trends during a volatile period.
content: The big increase in the murder rate in the United States in 2020 has carried over to 2021.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Nicas
title: Google reduces some app-store fees amid criticism.
description: Google said that starting July 1, it would take 15 percent of the first $1 million developers take in from certain app sales, down from 30 percent.
content: Google is cutting in half its commission on developers’ first $1 million in app sales, following a similar move by Apple that is aimed at appeasing developers and regulators who accuse the companies of abusing their dominance of the smartphone industry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Spencer Bokat-Lindell
title: Why Cuomo’s #MeToo Moment Hasn’t Brought Him Down
description: Top Democrats want him to resign. A lot of voters don’t.
content: This article is part of the Debatable newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it on Tuesdays and Thursdays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: Sports Books Plan an N.C.A.A. Party: Fans, Bets and Extra Bacon
description: The bonanza of betting on the men’s basketball tournament often rivals the Super Bowl. At casinos that lost big last year, the welcome mat is out.
content: For a fan, especially one who likes to gamble, there’s nothing quite like the atmosphere of a sports book during an N.C.A.A. basketball tournament. A packed house, multiple games on multiple televisions, throngs of fans enjoying a victory or tearing tickets in frustration at a defeat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bee Shapiro
title: The Freestyle Ski Star Eileen Gu Has a Warning About TikTok Diets
description: The skier, who is competing in the World Cup in Aspen, has some beauty and fitness tips, too.
content: Is the ski world ready for the next Shaun White? This iteration is 17-years-old, just got into Stanford and also models for a living. The freestyle skier Eileen Gu recently took home two gold medals and a bronze at the X Games (the first woman ever to win three medals as a rookie). She repeated her success this month, winning another two golds at the World Championships in Aspen, Colo., where she is training. You may also have seen her in a variety of fashion magazines, including the cover of InStyle China.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kathryn Shattuck
title: Alex Newell Finds Inspiration in Whitney Houston, Billy Porter and ‘Dreamgirls’
description: The “Zoey’s Extraordinary Playlist” star talked about the performers he recognizes himself in, coming full circle with Mariah Carey and his signature banana pudding.
content: It’s the line repeated every awards season — that it’s an honor just to be nominated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: Berlin Theater Back in Crisis After Director Quits
description: Klaus Dörr resigned as head of the Volksbühne after 10 women accused him of sexual harassment and creating a hostile work environment.
content: The director of the Volksbühne theater in Berlin quit on Monday after accusations of sexual harassment, creating a hostile work environment and humiliating older actresses were published in a German newspaper. Klaus Dörr had led the Volksbühne, one of Europe’s most influential theaters, since April 2018.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lara Jakes, Motoko Rich and John Ismay
title: Visiting Japan, Top U.S. Envoys Set Combative Tone for China Talks
description: American and Japanese officials issued a two-page statement that left little doubt that President Biden would defy Beijing in territorial disputes, challenges to democracy and other regional crises.
content: TOKYO — Just days before the Biden administration’s first face-to-face encounter with Beijing, two senior American envoys used a visit to Tokyo on Tuesday to set a confrontational tone for the talks, rebuking what they called “coercion” and “destabilizing actions” by China in its increasingly aggressive military forays in the region.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marie Fazio
title: A Meat War Is Waged Across State Lines
description: In a ceremonial effort to discourage meat consumption, the Colorado governor declared March 20 “MeatOut Day.” Then Nebraska’s governor announced “Meat on the Menu Day,” seeking to do just the opposite.
content: Depending on which side of the Colorado-Nebraska state line you’re standing on, the meat-related significance of March 20 varies drastically.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Malia Wollan
title: How to Wait in Line
description: Distract yourself to pass the time. If you can, embrace the camaraderie of wanting something en masse.
content: “The queuing delays you experience are a minuscule fraction of your total hours of life, so don’t let them be a major source of anxiety,” says Richard Larson, 77, a professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology who has studied queuing for 40 years. Any group of people waiting their turn for a service, wherever they are in physical space, is a queue. Larson came up with mathematical methods for predicting what he calls slips and skips, where a newcomer arrives after you but gets the service first: They skip up, you slip back. Such cutting doesn’t need to be intentional to feel unjust. “If you are the victim, you incur a psychological cost,” Larson says. “You can get angry or even violent.” Make every effort to relax instead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Perri Klass, M.D
title: How Children Read Differently From Books vs. Screens
description: Scrolling may work for social media, but experts say that for school assignments, kids learn better if they slow down their reading.
content: In this pandemic year, parents have been watching — often anxiously — their children’s increasing reliance on screens for every aspect of their education. It can feel as if there’s no turning back to the time when learning involved hitting the actual books.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carlotta Gall
title: Trial of Woman Who Killed Her Husband Highlights Domestic Abuse in Turkey
description: The case against Melek Ipek, who is being supported by women’s rights groups, has become a touchstone issue in Turkish politics.
content: ISTANBUL — Handcuffed and naked, Melek Ipek endured a night of beatings, sexual assault and death threats from her husband that left her and their two daughters battered and traumatized. By morning, after he went out and came back to the house, she had picked up a gun and killed him in a struggle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stacy Cowley and Jim Tankersley
title: Biden Highlights Small-Business Help, as Problems Persist With Lending Program
description: President Biden visited a Black-owned flooring company as he continued his weeklong push to highlight the $1.9 trillion economic relief package.
content: President Biden dropped by a flooring company in the Philadelphia suburbs on Tuesday to promote an assortment of measures in his $1.9 trillion aid package that are aimed at helping small employers and their workers endure the pandemic’s economic shocks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ezra Klein
title: Mark Bittman Cooked Everything. Now He Wants to Change Everything.
description: The acclaimed food writer offers a sweeping indictment of our modern food system.
content: Mark Bittman taught me to cook. I read his New York Times cooking column, “The Minimalist,” religiously. I bought “How to Cook Everything,” that red brick of a cookbook, and then, when I gave up meat, I bought its green companion, “How to Cook Everything Vegetarian.” He was like my cranky, no-B.S. food uncle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mara Altman
title: The Costly, Painful, Lonely Burden of Care
description: Health care in the U.S. relies on an “invisible army” of caregivers — mostly women. For many, stunted careers, lost earnings and exhaustion are part of the fallout.
content: — Kate Washington, the author of “Already Toast: Caregiving and Burnout in America”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Streitfeld
title: How Amazon Crushes Unions
description: In a secret settlement in Virginia, Amazon swore off threatening and intimidating workers. As the company confronts increased labor unrest, its tactics are under scrutiny.
content: RICHMOND, Va. — Five years ago, Amazon was compelled to post a “notice to employees” on the break-room walls of a warehouse in east-central Virginia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Mazzei
title: Florida Finds Election Fraud in High School Homecoming Votes
description: A student and her mother were arrested after the authorities found more than 100 votes suspiciously cast from a single school login.
content: MIAMI — The report about vote tampering reached the Florida Department of Law Enforcement in early November: Someone had gained access to electronic accounts without authorization. At least 117 votes had been suspiciously cast — in J.M. Tate High School’s election for homecoming court.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hannah Selinger
title: The Next Amenity? Furnished Condos
description: Developers are catering to buyers who want a true move-in experience, with the furniture already in place.
content: Developers looking for new ways to market apartments during the pandemic have decided that more is better, so they have begun to offer buyers furnished apartments, solving two design problems: many people are wary about shopping in stores and are also leery of the current backlogs in the home furnishings market.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ernesto Londoño and Letícia Casado
title: Brazil needs vaccines, and China is benefiting.
description: With Covid-19 deaths rising to their highest levels yet and a dangerous new virus variant stalking Brazil, the nation’s communications minister went to Beijing, where he met with Huawei executives and made an unusual request.
content: With Covid-19 deaths rising to their highest levels yet and a dangerous new virus variant stalking Brazil, the nation’s communications minister went to Beijing, where he met with Huawei executives and made an unusual request.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Gross
title: We Don’t Know How Much Art Has Gone Missing From Museums
description: Museums are doing a better job of accounting for missing inventory than years ago, when they would sometimes not report thefts out of embarrassment and fear of exposing security weaknesses.
content: Should museums tell the public about missing art?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Kenigsberg
title: ‘Martha: A Picture Story’ Review: Snapshots of a Career
description: This documentary recounts the work of Martha Cooper, a photographer instrumental in establishing the validity of street art.
content: “Martha: A Picture Story” turns the camera around on Martha Cooper, a photographer who captured the era when graffiti-covered subway cars crisscrossed New York, and who was among the first to give serious consideration to the artists who scrawled on those trains. The book “Subway Art,” Cooper’s 1984 collaboration with the photographer Henry Chalfant, developed an international underground following, providing a stylistic template — Cooper’s word — for aspiring graffiti writers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman and Jesse McKinley
title: How Cuomo’s Team Tried to Tarnish One of His Accusers
description: People tied to Gov. Andrew Cuomo sought to damage the credibility of Lindsey Boylan, the first woman to accuse Mr. Cuomo of sexual harassment.
content: Days after Lindsey Boylan became the first woman to accuse Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of sexual harassment in a series of Twitter posts in December, people tied to the governor started circulating an open letter that they hoped former staff members would sign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: North Korea’s Message to Biden: ‘Refrain From Causing a Stink’
description: The country took a confrontational stance against the United States in its first official remark directed at President Biden’s administration.
content: SEOUL — North Korea issued its first warning shot against the Biden administration on Tuesday, denouncing Washington for going forward with joint military exercises with South Korea and raising “a stink” on the Korean Peninsula.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Callie Holtermann
title: Learn 10 Commonly Confused Words With TikTok and The Times
description: Help students make sense of tricky words with TikTok videos from a member of our Teaching Project, and usage examples from The New York Times.
content: Many of us, whether at school or in the workplace, puzzle over how to use commonly confused words like affect and effect, farther and further, and capitol and capital.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Martin
title: Feinstein’s Future Could Swing on Husband’s Potential Posting Overseas
description: Senator Dianne Feinstein’s husband, Richard Blum, is seeking an overseas posting, which could pave the way for her to leave the Senate. She said she would “absolutely’’ serve out her term.
content: WASHINGTON — Richard Blum, a wealthy investor and the husband of Senator Dianne Feinstein of California, has indicated to President Biden’s advisers that he’s interested in being appointed to an ambassadorship, a move that would renew questions about Ms. Feinstein’s political future.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Grammys, Improbably, Made It Work
description: The show navigated a year of crisis, minted a new generation of stars and didn’t fixate on boomers.
content: So the Grammys this year were … good? Given the persistent clouds of uncertainty and scandal that have hovered over the ceremony and the voting process behind the awards in recent years, compounded by the impact of the coronavirus pandemic, it was a welcome surprise that the ceremony was, more or less, a success.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Taylor Lorenz
title: Squishmallows Are Taking Over
description: These huggable, collectible plush toys have cultivated a fandom in a year of grief, isolation and uncertainty.
content: Over the last few months, bulbous and brightly colored plush toys have sparked a Beanie Babies-style craze among children, teenagers and adults alike.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: ‘There Was No Mercy’
description: Amazon played hardball in opposing unionization drives.
content: Amazon faces a unionization drive at a warehouse in Bessemer, Ala. — the largest and most viable U.S. labor challenge in years. The Times’s David Streitfeld looked into the e-commerce giant’s previous efforts to block organized labor. He found a host of tough tactics … that worked. Will they again?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria Chang
title: How Chinese Dramas Helped Me Build a Relationship With My Sister
description: After our mom died, I turned to her beloved pastime for comfort. It opened up a new way to communicate with my family.
content: When I tell people my sister is 14 months older than me, some marvel at how close we must be. Others joke that my parents got busy fast. The joke is true, but my sister and I have never been close. We couldn’t be more different. I’m louder, taller and blunter. She’s quieter, shorter and sweeter. When we were young, I barreled through Michigan forests on my bike while she buried her head in Nancy Drew books. Because my sister was more obedient and a better student than I was, I perceived that she was the favored child.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: 8 Immigrants Killed in Border City Crash
description: The victims were riding in a pickup truck that was being chased by the police when it collided head-on with another pickup near Del Rio, Texas, the authorities said.
content: Eight immigrants were killed on Monday afternoon when a pickup truck they were riding in crashed head-on into another pickup during a police chase in southwestern Texas, the authorities said on Tuesday amid a deepening humanitarian crisis along the Mexican border.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Gessen
title: Sports Meant So Much to Me. Why Wouldn’t My Son Play?
description: In-line skating, soccer, hockey — my 5-year-old didn’t take to them. Was I doing something wrong?
content: I remember this: Raffi in the community garden. He is maybe 2 years old. I have brought along a soccer ball. He likes running back and forth in the garden, attacking people’s vegetables. Why not kick the ball while he’s at it? He is willing to do it. At first, he is always willing to do it. But he is not good at it. He misses the ball more often than he hits it. In order to keep him interested, I make a goal out of my legs. When, after numerous attempts, he finally scores, I pick him up and spin him around to celebrate. After that he doesn’t want to kick the ball anymore; he just wants to get picked up and spun around.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Edward C. Luck, Architect of U.N. Code on Genocide, Dies at 72
description: He transformed vague ideals into a strategy on when the world should collectively intervene to stop mass atrocities.
content: Edward C. Luck, a foreign policy adviser who was regarded as a conscience of the diplomatic community for devising strategies to prevent genocide and other mass atrocities, died on Feb. 16 at his home in Briarcliff Manor, N.Y. He was 72.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Nicas
title: Beer Here, Bouquets Next Door: How a Bar Defied the Pandemic
description: The Times followed the Hatch and its staff in Oakland after the pandemic began. The business not only survived, it’s expanding.
content: OAKLAND, Calif. — One year ago at the Hatch, a narrow neighborhood bar in downtown Oakland, dozens of unmasked people crowded inside to say goodbye for a while. California’s governor had just ordered the nation’s first effective coronavirus lockdown, and the bar’s staff and regulars thought they wouldn’t be back for weeks, maybe even months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Engle
title: Who Are the Best Musical Artists of the Past Year? What Are the Best Songs?
description: The 63rd annual Grammy Awards celebrated the music that emerged in a deeply challenging year. If you had a say, what music would you honor?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mimi Swartz
title: Beneath Her Decorous Demeanor, ‘Lady Bird Johnson’ Was a Political Force
description: The new biography, by Julia Sweig, shows the wife of Lyndon B. Johnson to have been ahead of her time (and possibly her husband) on women’s rights, racial disparities and other issues.
content: LADY BIRD JOHNSON Hiding in Plain SightBy Julia Sweig
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Greg Bensinger
title: Facebook Is Better Without Trump
description: Keep the ban of the former president in place.
content: If you are a public official, there’s no more effective or efficient place to lie than on Facebook. It’s company policy — meaning the policy of the chief executive, Mark Zuckerberg — to roll out the red carpet to all manner of political falsehood and obfuscation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Anthes
title: Three Feet or Six? Distancing Guideline for Schools Stirs Debate
description: Some public health officials say it’s time for the C.D.C. to loosen its social distancing guidelines for classrooms, but the idea has detractors.
content: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention is clear and consistent in its social distancing recommendation: To reduce the risk of contracting the coronavirus, people should remain at least six feet away from others who are not in their households. The guideline holds whether you are eating in a restaurant, lifting weights at a gym or learning long division in a fourth-grade classroom.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: WakuWaku, an Izakaya Counter in Industry City, Expands Outdoors
description: Counter-service Mediterranean in Midtown East, a new wine shop in Crown Heights and more restaurant news.
content: Tucked in the courtyard behind the sprawling Japan Village market and food hall in Brooklyn’s Industry City is a new extension of WakuWaku, an izakaya counter in the market. Partly open wooden structures designed to look like traditional Japanese houses, with plexiglass panels between tables, have been installed for year-round outdoor dining. There are also open-air tables, and the counter will remain open. The vast menu features Japanese Wagyu, notably a 6-ounce rib-eye steak finished on a tabletop grill, as well as sushi, sashimi, dumplings (including cheese won tons), udon noodle soup, yakitori skewers, fried kushi-age skewers, and small plates like grilled smelts, shiitakes stuffed with shrimp, and corn tempura. Larger dishes include salmon teriyaki, sukiyaki, shabu shabu and that Wagyu rib-eye ($55).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Burdick
title: The Pandemic and the Limits of Science
description: What have we learned from the year that lasted a century?
content: “The pandemic which has just swept round the earth has been without precedent.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin Pogrebin
title: Affordable Housing Earns French Couple the Pritzker Prize
description: After more than 30 years of designing affordable new spaces out of existing structures, Anne Lacaton and Jean-Philippe Vassal have won architecture’s highest honor.
content: Anne Lacaton and Jean-Philippe Vassal have never demolished a building in order to construct a new one.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anita Gates
title: Nicola Pagett, ‘Upstairs, Downstairs’ Actress, Dies at 75
description: She preferred the stage, but she won praise for her work on television as the rebellious and thoroughly spoiled Elizabeth Bellamy, and later as Anna Karenina.

title: I Lived Through the AIDS Crisis and Now Covid. N.Y.C. Got Me Through.
description: In this new short film, an artist finds hope in an unlikely place — the city’s storefront gates, rolling up day after day.
content: For almost three decades, I’ve been making visual art with New York City at its center. I’m especially drawn to everyday moments that, when you focus on them, have unexpected emotional power: the riveted expressions of lunchgoers scanning a salad bar, the split-second disorientation of commuters emerging from the subway onto the street. I work mostly in public, but I don’t know how to do that right now. So I find myself looking back on footage I shot in the past to try to make sense of the present. In the short documentary above, I revisited a video I shot in the early 1990s, of shopkeepers near my East Village apartment throwing open their gates in the morning, to reflect on the perpetual change and resilience that mark life in New York City.

President Donald Trump managed the executive branch as his own fief, mocking the markers Congress had set down to secure its interests in government. Mr. Trump purged inspectors general and removed an F.B.I. director, brushing aside protections Congress established in law for their independence. He installed loyalists in acting positions, flouting the Senate’s confirmation process, and weakened protections for career professionals. He defied Congress’s power of the purse and its oversight authority.

description: Part craft project and part meditation on the evolution of domestic space, these miniature paper dwellings can be assembled with just scissors and glue.
content: In a way, the origins of paper cutting as an art form predate the invention of paper itself, a world-historic achievement often attributed to the Chinese eunuch and court official Cai Lun, who presented his experiments with dried bamboo-and-mulberry pulp to the Emperor Ho Ti in 105 A.D. Prior to this innovation, craftspeople across rural China were already cutting decorative shapes from thin sheets of silk, gold foil and tree bark. As paper became more common in the 7th century, though, the art of paper cutting, or jianzhi, flourished. “While calligraphy reflects the intellectual culture, paternal tradition and written history,” wrote Crystal Hui-Shu Yang, a scholar of Chinese folk art, in a 2007 essay on the cross-cultural exchange between jianzhi artisans and Swiss practitioners of scherenschnitte, the form’s central European iteration, which emerged in the 16th century, “paper cutting represents illiterate culture, maternal tradition and oral history.” From the beginning, then, there has been an appealingly intimate, democratic quality to the craft.
